name: asclepias stenophylla
description:
New! Narrow-Leaved Milkweed is easily distinguished from other
Asclepias species by its widely-spaced, opposite leaves that are only about
¼-inch wide but up to six inches long. Believed to have naturally migrated from
the western Ozarks, this plant prefers full sun and well-drained soils, often
rocky or sandy range lands or hillside prairies. The species has protected
status in some northern parts of its range, where it is rarer than in the Lower
Plains. A larval host and nectar source for Monarchs, this species’ plants
bloom through the summer months in hues ranging from white to greenish, with
occasional hints of light yellow. The seed pods are narrowly tapered, echoing
the form of the plant’s foliage.
features: Pollinator Favorite: butterflies, bees and birds
Deer Resistant (Our experiences here in the Upper Midwest may vary in other regions; deer can respond differently to local conditions or seasonal variations.)
